feed.title: Stories by Naqeeb ali Shamsi on Medium
feed.description: Stories by Naqeeb ali Shamsi on Medium

items.title: Map Reduce Word count with Apache Spark [JAVA17][Win10]
items.author: Naqeeb ali Shamsi
items.description:
To configure spark locally:

Environment -> (Win 10; Java version = 17.x)

  • Download latest version of spark from here.
  • Download hadoop winutils and dlls from here (Follow the README in the repo)
  • Set up environment variables:
  • %SPARK_HOME% (Path of the extracted spark folder)
  • %HADOOP_HOME%
  • Add the environment variables to the PATH variable (under system variables):
  • %SPARK_HOME%\bin
  • %HADOOP_HOME%\bin
  • Copy the hadoop.dll file from the hadoop directory and paste it under C:\Windows\System32
  • Restart PC
  • Before executing the code, add the following VM options:

Paste the following options besides Environment Variables:

  • -add-opens=java.base/java.lang=ALL-UNNAMED --add-opens=java.base/java.lang.invoke=ALL-UNNAMED --add-opens=java.base/java.lang.reflect=ALL-UNNAMED --add-opens=java.base/java.io=ALL-UNNAMED --add-opens=java.base/java.net=ALL-UNNAMED --add-opens=java.base/java.nio=ALL-UNNAMED --add-opens=java.base/java.util=ALL-UNNAMED --add-opens=java.base/java.util.concurrent=ALL-UNNAMED --add-opens=java.base/java.util.concurrent.atomic=ALL-UNNAMED --add-opens=java.base/sun.nio.ch=ALL-UNNAMED --add-opens=java.base/sun.nio.cs=ALL-UNNAMED --add-opens=java.base/sun.security.action=ALL-UNNAMED --add-opens=java.base/sun.util.calendar=ALL-UNNAMED --add-opens=java.security.jgss/sun.security.krb5=ALL-UNNAMED

Project dependencies:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<project xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0"
         xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
         xsi:schemaLocation="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0 http://maven.apache.org/xsd/maven-4.0.0.xsd">
    <modelVersion>4.0.0</modelVersion>

    <groupId>org.example</groupId>
    <artifactId>WordCount</artifactId>
    <version>1.0-SNAPSHOT</version>

    <properties>
        <maven.compiler.source>17</maven.compiler.source>
        <maven.compiler.target>17</maven.compiler.target>
        <project.build.sourceEncoding>UTF-8</project.build.sourceEncoding>
    </properties>
    <dependencies>
        <dependency>
            <groupId>org.apache.spark</groupId>
            <artifactId>spark-core_2.13</artifactId>
            <version>3.3.1</version>
        </dependency>
    </dependencies>

</project>

Map Reduce code

import org.apache.commons.io.FileUtils;
import org.apache.spark.SparkConf;
import org.apache.spark.api.java.JavaPairRDD;
import org.apache.spark.api.java.JavaRDD;
import org.apache.spark.api.java.JavaSparkContext;
import scala.Tuple2;

public class WordCount {
    private static void wordCount(String filename) {
        SparkConf sparkConf = new SparkConf().setMaster("local").setAppName("Word Counter");
        JavaSparkContext javaSparkContext = new JavaSparkContext(sparkConf);
        JavaRDD<String> input_file = javaSparkContext.textFile(filename);
        JavaRDD<String> wordsInFile = input_file.flatMap(content -> Arrays.asList(content.split(" ")).iterator());
        JavaPairRDD<String, Integer> wordCount = wordsInFile.mapToPair(t -> new Tuple2<>(t, 1)).reduceByKey((x, y) -> x + (int) y);
        wordCount.saveAsTextFile("WC_MAPREDUCE_OUTPUT");
    }
public static void main(String[] args){
  wordCount("<your-file-path>");
}

To see your output,

Navigate to your project directory and open “WC_MAPREDUCE_OUTPUT>part-00000”

To configure spark locally:

Environment -> (Win 10; Java version = 17.x)

  • Download latest version of spark from here.
  • Download hadoop winutils and dlls from here (Follow the README in the repo)
  • Set up environment variables:
  • %SPARK_HOME% (Path of the extracted spark folder)
  • %HADOOP_HOME%
  • Add the environment variables to the PATH variable (under system variables):
  • %SPARK_HOME%\bin
  • %HADOOP_HOME%\bin
  • Copy the hadoop.dll file from the hadoop directory and paste it under C:\Windows\System32
  • Restart PC
  • Before executing the code, add the following VM options:

Paste the following options besides Environment Variables:

  • -add-opens=java.base/java.lang=ALL-UNNAMED --add-opens=java.base/java.lang.invoke=ALL-UNNAMED --add-opens=java.base/java.lang.reflect=ALL-UNNAMED --add-opens=java.base/java.io=ALL-UNNAMED --add-opens=java.base/java.net=ALL-UNNAMED --add-opens=java.base/java.nio=ALL-UNNAMED --add-opens=java.base/java.util=ALL-UNNAMED --add-opens=java.base/java.util.concurrent=ALL-UNNAMED --add-opens=java.base/java.util.concurrent.atomic=ALL-UNNAMED --add-opens=java.base/sun.nio.ch=ALL-UNNAMED --add-opens=java.base/sun.nio.cs=ALL-UNNAMED --add-opens=java.base/sun.security.action=ALL-UNNAMED --add-opens=java.base/sun.util.calendar=ALL-UNNAMED --add-opens=java.security.jgss/sun.security.krb5=ALL-UNNAMED

<project xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0"
         xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
         xsi:schemaLocation="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0 http://maven.apache.org/xsd/maven-4.0.0.xsd">

    <groupId>org.example</groupId>
    <artifactId>WordCount</artifactId>
    <version>1.0-SNAPSHOT</version>

    <properties>
        <maven.compiler.source>17</maven.compiler.source>
        <maven.compiler.target>17</maven.compiler.target>
        <project.build.sourceEncoding>UTF-8</project.build.sourceEncoding>
    </properties>
    <dependencies>
        <dependency>
            <groupId>org.apache.spark</groupId>
            <artifactId>spark-core_2.13</artifactId>
            <version>3.3.1</version>
        </dependency>
    </dependencies>

</project>

import org.apache.commons.io.FileUtils;
import org.apache.spark.SparkConf;
import org.apache.spark.api.java.JavaPairRDD;
import org.apache.spark.api.java.JavaRDD;
import org.apache.spark.api.java.JavaSparkContext;
import scala.Tuple2;

public class WordCount {
    private static void wordCount(String filename) {
        SparkConf sparkConf = new SparkConf().setMaster("local").setAppName("Word Counter");
        JavaSparkContext javaSparkContext = new JavaSparkContext(sparkConf);
        JavaRDD<String> input_file = javaSparkContext.textFile(filename);
        JavaRDD<String> wordsInFile = input_file.flatMap(content -> Arrays.asList(content.split(" ")).iterator());
        JavaPairRDD<String, Integer> wordCount = wordsInFile.mapToPair(t -> new Tuple2<>(t, 1)).reduceByKey((x, y) -> x + (int) y);
        wordCount.saveAsTextFile("WC_MAPREDUCE_OUTPUT");
    }
public static void main(String[] args){
  wordCount("<your-file-path>");
}

To see your output,

Navigate to your project directory and open “WC_MAPREDUCE_OUTPUT>part-00000”

items.title: Case Study: Enhance the experience of working from home.
items.author: Naqeeb ali Shamsi
items.description:
Adapting to the change.

I finally started with what I always wanted to since a long time. I got enrolled in the UX Mastery Program designed by GrowthSchool and this Design Thinking project is the first milestone in the journey. Hope you find this exciting as I do!

We were given this project to get familiar with the process in a non-textbook approach and understand our users better. We were sorted into groups of 5–8 students each and each group was assigned a different part of the house on which we had to prepare a case study defining the problems of the user related to that part of the house and come with ideas to solve them. Each member of a group would then go on interviewing the other members for their problems by considering them as their users.

Let’s dive right in!

What is Design Thinking you ask?

It is a process that starts with empathizing with the users and identifying their problems and gaining insights by putting yourself in their shoes. Then we define those problems and come up with ideas to solve those problems and come up with a solution that best solves the users’ problems.

The Empathize Stage

This is the first and most important stage of the process as this is where we converse with the users and identify their problems through a series of questions.

Asking the right questions is what we’ll need to master at this stage. This shall come only from experience.

Following are the questions that I asked my users:

Hi! what do you do (work/study)? And since how long have you been doing it?
2. Has the pandemic affected your work/study. In what way?
3. How have you been adapting to WFH?
4. Do you live with your family/roommates/alone?
5. What part of your home is the home office?
6. What furniture items do you use in your home office?
7. Describe the ambiance of your home office. Does it affect your work and how?
8. What equipment/devices do you require for working?
9. How efficient/organized is your workspace? Rate 1–10.
10. What do you do when taking a break from work?
11. How would you rate your workspace comfort? Rate 1–10.
12. Imagine you had an infinite amount of resources. Quantify the amount of modification you’d do to your workspace. 1=> No modification needed. Everything is perfect the way it is. 10 => Needs a complete makeover. Explain your rating.

These are the base questions. Every iteration, these questions got modified according to the previous answers.

USER1 [GIRISH]

“Mining Engineer.
Reserved dude with a good sense of empathy.”
Has an on-field job.
Lives in a shared space with fellow roommates and uses the hall area for studying.
Uses a hall(shared space) on another floor as his study area.
Uses a shelf, an old table, and a chair which was present from before he rented the place.
Studies not more than 2 hrs. And during that time, there is no noticeable disturbance.
Comfort: 5/10
Reasons:
“Lighting is not comfortable”
“Chair is not comfortable for sitting for an extended period.”
Room for modification: 7/10.
Explanation: “I would love to have a comfortable chair and install lights in the hall area where I study.”

USER2 [Swagatika]

“Tenacious.”
Lives with her family.
Enrolled for the UX mastery and does nothing else apart from that. Focused!
When subjected to study from home, she was devastated and couldn’t cope with studying alone, without social interaction.
Uses her bedroom as the study. Quite a peaceful environment. No disturbance except the occasional visits from her dog.
Uses a chair and a table that can accommodate the required items for her study (laptop and notebook).
Workspace organization: 6/10.
Comfort: 8/10
Reasons: “I am quite comfortable in my existing workspace.”
“I am uncomfortable with the solitude due to the pandemic.”
Room for modification: 5/10
Explanation: “I want my workspace to look good”

USER3 [ABHISHEK]

“SME & Content creator for an edtech startup.
Chill dude.”

  • Been working professionally for 3 yrs.
  • WFH lives with his family.
  • Feels like WFH was the best professional “accident” that happened.
  • “Gets enough time for other activities/hobbies”
  • Uses his bedroom as the home office.
  • Has 2 tables but prefers to work while on his bed.
  • Says working on the bed gives more freedom of movement and can work in a more “chilled-out” manner.
  • Listens to music while on breaks from work and sometimes strolls on his balcony.
  • Long work hours and sometimes completes his work after hours.
  • Has a younger brother who screams all day and has the usual distractions from other family members.
  • Says his workspace doesn’t need organization as he just uses his laptop for most of his work and hence, Workspace Organization 9/10.
  • Feels extremely comfortable with his workspace (his bed) and rates it 9/10.
  • Room for modification: 10/10
  • Says he wants to declutter his room; Has a mandir in his room which needs to be shifted somewhere else; Needs a bean bag; Needs more floor space in the room; Would feel more comfortable not using a table and sitting on the ground while working.

USER4 [ROSHNI]

“Tech analyst.
Comfort enthusiast”
Was NOT prepared for WFH. Felt weird and had a lot of connectivity issues.
Did not have a proper table and had to manage with boxes from amazon for a makeshift table. Adapted gradually. Had back pain initially.
No apparent distractions at home as she lives with her husband only.
Feels strongly about the excess work hours while WFH. Feels like they’re taken for granted, with no value for personal time.
Invested in a breakfast table (“portable desk”) which can be taken anywhere around the house while working.
Does not have a fixed place for working, the whole house is her workspace.
The table is large enough to accommodate her laptop and notebook.
Workspace comfort: 7/10. (Need an “office” chair)
Feels that working from the office was better as she could have time for herself and her family after reaching home.
Room for modification: 3/10
Explanation:
Get a comfortable chair.
Add some soundproofing panels.

USER5 [ANURAG]

“Content writer
‘PRO’-crastinator.”
Lives with family. WFH
Feels like he was more efficient & focused while working from the office.
Went back and forth to work from the office and WFH during the course of the pandemic.
WFH likes: no office etiquette needs to be followed.
WFH dislike: gets confusing; no barrier b/w personal & office life.
Uses his bedroom as the home office.
Uses a table, a chair, Laptop, iPad.
No apparent problems in the ambiance.
While taking a break, he mostly watches a movie or an episode of a TV series.
Feels that no organization of workspace is needed.
He thought he’d use his free time to learn stuff but fell victim to procrastination and distractions.
Workspace comfort: 8/10
Explanation:
Fairly comfy
Natural sunlight & breezy.
The charging point is a bit away from the table.
Not enough space for extra laptops.
Sometimes the curtains get irritating due to the breeze. -_-
Room for modification: 6/10.
Explanation:
Solve the charging point problem.
Use a spike guard.
Buy a more comfortable chair.
Add a footstool to rest legs.
Minimal decor to improve workspace aesthetics.

Though different, the users had similarities in their stories which I noticed after interviewing 3 users. I’ll discuss them in the next stage.

The Define Stage

After listening to the users’ problems, we progress to the define stage where we identify the problems from the insights given by the users and sort them into broad categories.

I sorted the problems into the following categories:

  1. Comfort
  2. Ambiance
  3. Aesthetics
  4. Space

Then I created 8 problem statements from the users’ stories.

- Uncomfortable seating:
While working for long hours while being seated (laying down in some cases), the users feel discomfort which is a natural response of the body and may pose back-pain problems.
- Ambience(low-light):
1 user complained about the ambience of their home-office that there was a low-light situation at night( the time in which they usually use the workspace). It is straightforward discomforting to the eyes and may lead to eye-problems if it continues.
- Ambient Noise:
It is a distraction/discomfort to the ears of the user while working.
- Aesthetics:
2 users mentioned that good aesthetics of their workplace will help them sustain a good mood throughout the workday.
- Uncomfortable seat/chair:
This is important to the users as the chair is the piece of furniture that they spend most of their time during working hours and users feeling discomfort after being seated for a long time directly impacts their health and work.
- Less floor space in the room:
The room appears to be cluttered and the workspace looks unorganised and ugly to the user which could restrict the user’s movement which is a form of discomfort.
- Charging port not near to the desk:
This problem is fairly important as the user works mostly on their laptop, ipad and mobile phone device and to charge them, they have to move their devices in the range of the charging ports in their bedroom which is a great inconvenience while working.
- No furniture item to rest legs while sitting in a chair:
This problem is important to the user as they want to rest their legs while sitting in a chair so that they’re in a more comfortable position.

Now that we have defined problem statements, it is time to put on our creative hats and form ideas to solve the problems defined in this stage

The Ideate Stage

https://medium.com/media/ac801b581d4cefcae509187ebb9596c7/href

I was excited about this stage the most. I had a lot of ideas flowing through my head but, most of them unreal or impractical. I used the crazy 8 technique (8 ideas in 8 min for each problem) and noted down the ones which were viable.

1. Buy a gaming chair or a chair with lumbar support.
2. Buy a portable desk with built-in charging.
3. Organize and declutter the workspace.
4. Install acoustic panels and or a rubber frame for the doors/windows to reduce noise from outside.
5. Buy an LED lamp/light.
6. Comfortable chair with built-in desk and charging.
7. Leg stool.
8. Spike guard for extending the range of charging points.
9. To improve aesthetics, establish a desk and a chair in the workspace with the user’s choice of decor.
10. To improve aesthetics, indoor plants can be placed in the workspace.
11. Recliner chair with built-in desk and charging for ultimate comfort.
12. Noise-cancelling headphones for total cut-off when working in a shared space.

Out of all these, I had to choose the top 3 ideas:

1. Recliner chair with built-in desk and charging ports. Paired with noise-cancelling headphones.
Reason to pick this: This chair can be placed anywhere in the house according to the user’s liking (hence resolving the problems of aesthetics, less floor-space and low ambient light; it is comfort maximus; headphones resolve the problem of ambient noise and can be used for mid-work entertainment/music-listening too!
2. Portable desk with built-in charging.
Reason to pick this: Similar to the one above, but this one also caters to the users who prefer to more portability. It is a comfort maximus too.
3. Organise and declutter the workspace paired with decor and indoor plants.
Reason to pick this: This simple idea holds the power to completely transform the user’s workspace into something much better. It’ll work for users who give more attention to the ambience and aesthetics of their workplace.

I chose Idea #1 to progress to the next stage of prototyping.

The Prototype Stage

Let's get a brief of what we’ve done up till now.

PROBLEM STATEMENT: Enhance the experience of working from home.
IDEA: Recliner chair with built-in desk and charging ports. Paired with noise-cancelling headphones.

I sketched out my idea onto a piece of paper and it looked something like this:

Recliner Chair comfort Maximus (prototype-1)

This recliner chair will have the following features:

  1. Recliner (made of foam and mesh)(Solves the comfort problem)
  2. Leg rest (Solves the comfort problem)
  3. Lumbar support (Solves the back-pain problem)
  4. Built-in desk (Good to have feature)
  5. Wide enough to support a laptop, tablet, and mobile phone at any given time.
  6. USB charging dock with 4 outlets.
  7. Cupholder.
  8. A sliding drawer to keep a notepad and some stationery handy.
  9. Built-in power bank (housed inside the column) (Solves the far away from charging point problem and supports portability)
    Can be charged by plugging into a conventional A/C power supply.
  10. Portable (Wheels at the base) (Solves the aesthetics problem)

Overview:

The chair will have adjustable leg rest and recliner features with lumbar support (to support the spinal cord and prevent health issues) that will give its user maximum comfort while working, studying, entertainment, or just chilling.

After this stage, we need to immediately test it and iterate to eliminate any preliminary issues that may render the prototype unuseful.

The Test Stage

Time to test our prototype by taking it back to the users.

User 1 (Swagatika)
A well-planned design. Solves all the problems that I mentioned and gives much more features than expected. One problem that what if the user reclines fully and the desk is not needed? It will obstruct the user and will cause discomfort. Overall, great job!
Rated: 8/10
User 2 (Abhishek)
This product will surely give me the comfort I need. I’d definitely buy it if it was on the market. I always have to keep my laptop plugged in since it's become old and the battery is not as efficient. Don’t know how long will the power bank hold up.
Rated: 9/10
User 3 (Girish)
A great design. Would love to own one. I have the same problem that my laptop has an inefficient battery and needs to be plugged in always.
Rated: 9/10
User 4 (Roshni)
Good design. What if the user tilts the desk and the laptop slides down on their face?
How will you stop this? Other than that, quite a comfortable design.
Rated: 8/10

I immediately made a few changes to my design to fix the issues that’d outright render my design useless.

After revising, the users were satisfied enough.

Future design scope

Make it look more aesthetic.
Make the desk detachable.

From the feedback that my users gave, I figured out that the scope mentioned above would improve my prototype but the changes weren’t necessary.

Learnings from this project

Never start thinking about solutions in the Empathy stage. Be a good listener!
Unlearn what you already know about UX Design. This process is more fluent in nature and a non-textbook approach is the best approach.
Always think from the user’s perspective.
You can’t solve every problem.
Never stop learning!
#studentforlife #S4L
https://medium.com/media/4def1999c6cac3ff03404237ed1a895f/href

Natural sunlight & breezy.
The charging point is a bit away from the table.
Not enough space for extra laptops.
Sometimes the curtains get irritating due to the breeze. -_-
Room for modification: 6/10.
Explanation:
Solve the charging point problem.
Use a spike guard.
Buy a more comfortable chair.
Add a footstool to rest legs.
Minimal decor to improve workspace aesthetics.

Though different, the users had similarities in their stories which I noticed after interviewing 3 users. I’ll discuss them in the next stage.

The Define Stage

After listening to the users’ problems, we progress to the define stage where we identify the problems from the insights given by the users and sort them into broad categories.

I sorted the problems into the following categories:

  1. Comfort
  2. Ambiance
  3. Aesthetics
  4. Space

Then I created 8 problem statements from the users’ stories.

- Uncomfortable seating:
While working for long hours while being seated (laying down in some cases), the users feel discomfort which is a natural response of the body and may pose back-pain problems.
- Ambience(low-light):
1 user complained about the ambience of their home-office that there was a low-light situation at night( the time in which they usually use the workspace). It is straightforward discomforting to the eyes and may lead to eye-problems if it continues.
- Ambient Noise:
It is a distraction/discomfort to the ears of the user while working.
- Aesthetics:
2 users mentioned that good aesthetics of their workplace will help them sustain a good mood throughout the workday.
- Uncomfortable seat/chair:
This is important to the users as the chair is the piece of furniture that they spend most of their time during working hours and users feeling discomfort after being seated for a long time directly impacts their health and work.
- Less floor space in the room:
The room appears to be cluttered and the workspace looks unorganised and ugly to the user which could restrict the user’s movement which is a form of discomfort.
- Charging port not near to the desk:
This problem is fairly important as the user works mostly on their laptop, ipad and mobile phone device and to charge them, they have to move their devices in the range of the charging ports in their bedroom which is a great inconvenience while working.
- No furniture item to rest legs while sitting in a chair:
This problem is important to the user as they want to rest their legs while sitting in a chair so that they’re in a more comfortable position.

Now that we have defined problem statements, it is time to put on our creative hats and form ideas to solve the problems defined in this stage

The Ideate Stage

https://medium.com/media/ac801b581d4cefcae509187ebb9596c7/href

I was excited about this stage the most. I had a lot of ideas flowing through my head but, most of them unreal or impractical. I used the crazy 8 technique (8 ideas in 8 min for each problem) and noted down the ones which were viable.

1. Buy a gaming chair or a chair with lumbar support.
2. Buy a portable desk with built-in charging.
3. Organize and declutter the workspace.
4. Install acoustic panels and or a rubber frame for the doors/windows to reduce noise from outside.
5. Buy an LED lamp/light.
6. Comfortable chair with built-in desk and charging.
7. Leg stool.
8. Spike guard for extending the range of charging points.
9. To improve aesthetics, establish a desk and a chair in the workspace with the user’s choice of decor.
10. To improve aesthetics, indoor plants can be placed in the workspace.
11. Recliner chair with built-in desk and charging for ultimate comfort.
12. Noise-cancelling headphones for total cut-off when working in a shared space.

Out of all these, I had to choose the top 3 ideas:

1. Recliner chair with built-in desk and charging ports. Paired with noise-cancelling headphones.
Reason to pick this: This chair can be placed anywhere in the house according to the user’s liking (hence resolving the problems of aesthetics, less floor-space and low ambient light; it is comfort maximus; headphones resolve the problem of ambient noise and can be used for mid-work entertainment/music-listening too!
2. Portable desk with built-in charging.
Reason to pick this: Similar to the one above, but this one also caters to the users who prefer to more portability. It is a comfort maximus too.
3. Organise and declutter the workspace paired with decor and indoor plants.
Reason to pick this: This simple idea holds the power to completely transform the user’s workspace into something much better. It’ll work for users who give more attention to the ambience and aesthetics of their workplace.

I chose Idea #1 to progress to the next stage of prototyping.

The Prototype Stage

Let's get a brief of what we’ve done up till now.

PROBLEM STATEMENT: Enhance the experience of working from home.
IDEA: Recliner chair with built-in desk and charging ports. Paired with noise-cancelling headphones.

I sketched out my idea onto a piece of paper and it looked something like this:

Recliner Chair comfort Maximus (prototype-1)

This recliner chair will have the following features:

  1. Recliner (made of foam and mesh)(Solves the comfort problem)
  2. Leg rest (Solves the comfort problem)
  3. Lumbar support (Solves the back-pain problem)
  4. Built-in desk (Good to have feature)
  5. Wide enough to support a laptop, tablet, and mobile phone at any given time.
  6. USB charging dock with 4 outlets.
  7. Cupholder.
  8. A sliding drawer to keep a notepad and some stationery handy.
  9. Built-in power bank (housed inside the column) (Solves the far away from charging point problem and supports portability)
    Can be charged by plugging into a conventional A/C power supply.
  10. Portable (Wheels at the base) (Solves the aesthetics problem)

Overview:

The chair will have adjustable leg rest and recliner features with lumbar support (to support the spinal cord and prevent health issues) that will give its user maximum comfort while working, studying, entertainment, or just chilling.

After this stage, we need to immediately test it and iterate to eliminate any preliminary issues that may render the prototype unuseful.

The Test Stage

Time to test our prototype by taking it back to the users.

User 1 (Swagatika)
A well-planned design. Solves all the problems that I mentioned and gives much more features than expected. One problem that what if the user reclines fully and the desk is not needed? It will obstruct the user and will cause discomfort. Overall, great job!
Rated: 8/10
User 2 (Abhishek)
This product will surely give me the comfort I need. I’d definitely buy it if it was on the market. I always have to keep my laptop plugged in since it's become old and the battery is not as efficient. Don’t know how long will the power bank hold up.
Rated: 9/10
User 3 (Girish)
A great design. Would love to own one. I have the same problem that my laptop has an inefficient battery and needs to be plugged in always.
Rated: 9/10
User 4 (Roshni)
Good design. What if the user tilts the desk and the laptop slides down on their face?
How will you stop this? Other than that, quite a comfortable design.
Rated: 8/10

I immediately made a few changes to my design to fix the issues that’d outright render my design useless.

After revising, the users were satisfied enough.

Future design scope

Make it look more aesthetic.
Make the desk detachable.

From the feedback that my users gave, I figured out that the scope mentioned above would improve my prototype but the changes weren’t necessary.

Learnings from this project

Never start thinking about solutions in the Empathy stage. Be a good listener!
Unlearn what you already know about UX Design. This process is more fluent in nature and a non-textbook approach is the best approach.
Always think from the user’s perspective.
You can’t solve every problem.
Never stop learning!
#studentforlife #S4L
